description: Checklist for any website to ensure it's safe and secure for both the user and the business.

items.item: Website is served only over https
items.additional_description: This prevents data from being manipulated or intercepted
Installing a Strict-Transport-Security header, it would be extremely difficult for attackers to steal data

items.item: Is the server certificate 4096 bits or more?
items.additional_description: Long-term future-proof key length is desired since the trouble of replacing signatures is pretty high

items.item: Is TLS1.2 the only supported protocol?
items.additional_description: Through this security protocol, a system can communicate with the involved party. The encrypted data would not be deciphered by intruders

items.item: Supported symmetric ciphers use 256 bit keys or more
items.additional_description: This bit size is the largest and it is unbreakable by brute force

items.item: Ensure your content cannot be embedded in a frame on other websites
items.additional_description: Cross-domain iframes can run malicious apps, trigger alerts, autoplay videos, and induce phishing.

items.item: Deliver assets through a content delivery network
items.additional_description: This ensures fast delivery of Internet content

items.item: Ensure password entropy checks are carried out during sign-up
items.additional_description: This predicts the difficulty quotient of cracking a password by guess work, brute force, and dictionary attacks

items.item: Store only hash of user passwords
items.additional_description: Do not invent your own algorithm for repated hashing. Use PBKDF2, scrypt, or bcrypt

items.item: Ban IP addresses after a certain number of unsuccessful attempts
items.additional_description: For high risk sites, it is advisable to block an IP address after n number of unsuccessful attempts. Also, redirect the users to a message explaining the block, such as "malicious activity has been detected"

items.item: What are you using to control ssh login attempts?
items.additional_description: The most common suggestion is to turn off daemon service, which is sometimes a default installation. Use alternate authentication methods, instead of simple passwords.

items.item: Ensure hash salts, database passwords, and server signing keys are not checked into source control
items.additional_description: This would throttle data breaches. Salt hash is the basis of secure password storage. By putting the passwords in source control, anyine who has access to the repository can see your data.

items.item: Unit tests to ensure one person cannot access another user's content
items.additional_description: In a multi-tenant environment or role based access structure, authorization gets ignored and users via reverse engineering can get access to other user's data.

items.item: Validate form fields with restrictive regex
items.additional_description: Regular expressions or regex help in defining a whitelist for input validation. Input validation is the first line line of defense during the creation of a secure app

items.item: Do forms set a cross-site request forgery cookie?
items.additional_description: Cross-site request forgery attacks force an end-user to carry unwanted actions on a site they are authenticated in

items.item: Do session cookies have the 'Secure' and 'HttpOnly' flag set?
items.additional_description: Secure flags send the cookies only over HTTPS. HttpOnly flags prevents JavaScript from reading the cookies in case of XSS exploitation
